qas.question: What former studio in Jacksonville has been converted to a modern film Museum?

context: In the 1910s, <a0_0><a0_2>New York–based <a0_1><b4_0>filmmakers<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> were attracted to Jacksonville's warm climate, exotic locations, excellent rail access, and cheap labor. Over the course of the decade, more than 30 <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>silent<a1_2/> film<a1_1/><a1_0/> studios were established, earning Jacksonville the title of "<a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>Winter Film Capital of the World<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>". However, <a3_2>the emergence of <a3_0><a3_1><b5_0>Hollywood<b5_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> as a major film production center ended the city's film industry. One converted movie studio site, <b7_0>Norman Studios<b7_0/>, remains in Arlington; It has been converted to the Jacksonville Silent Film Museum at Norman Studios.
